OVERVIEW

Air Liquide Large Industries, L.P. (Air Liquide) Freeport Hydrogen purification unit (Freeport HPU) proces  in located within the Dow Freeport complex  in Freeport, Texas.  The Freeport HPU process involves the recovery and purification of hydrogen from by-product raw gas feedstock. Freeport HPU is considered the "covered process", as defined under the accidental release prevention regulations, as a "flammable mixture" process having in excess of 10,000 pounds.

 

Regulated Chemical and Covered Process 

The HPU process is designed to provide an efficient production of high purity hydrogen product using hydrogen rich byproduct raw gas feedstock streams from other chemical processes.   The purification is performed at elevated pressure. High pressure purified hydrogen is sold to Industrial customer(s).   The Freeport HPU is designed for continuous operation and is designed for inherently safe operation.

 



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

Air Liquide Freeport HPU is covered by EPA's accidental release prevention program regulations and is subject to OSHA's process safety management (PSM) standard.   The Freeport HPU process is closely monitored and controlled to prevent accidental releases to the environment.  

The flammability of the process makes it necessary to put in place safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community.  Air Liquide's policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The summary below discusses the process safety system in place to implement the accidental release prevention program.

 

Process Safety Information (PSI)

Air Liquide keeps a variety of technical documents onsite electronically that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, speci

fic chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely. 

 

Process Hazard Analysis

Air Liquide has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and continues to undergo periodic PHA's and PHA re-validations at least every five years.  The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards.   The PHA team will review findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Air Liquide action item tracking system. 

 

Operating Procedures

Air Liquide maintains written procedures that address various modes of hydrogen purification process operations, such as (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal and temporary operations; (3) unit shutdown; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) startup following an emergency shutdown; and (6) process deviation, consequence and action.  These procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

 

Training

Air Liquide has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating the hydrogen purification process.  All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topic as:  general orientation, site rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response.  In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years.  Training is documented and tracked the electronic learning management system.

 

Mechanical Integrity

Air Liquid

e has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on preventative philosophy, to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, and relief valves and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

 

The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

 

Management of Change

Air Liquide's management of change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved, and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process.  The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned changes.  All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subjective matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked, and closed.  Personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by the MOC, are briefed and /or trained in the MOC requirements.

 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

Air Liquide ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that:  (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate;

(3) PHAs have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed for affected employees.

 

Compliance Audits

To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Air Liquide conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  Resolutions to the recommendations are documented, tracked and closed.

 

Incident Investigation

Air Liquide defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure.  Air Liquide documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure.  Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings. 

 

 Employee Participation

At the La Porte SMR, employees are expected to participate in accidental release prevention program (PSM/RMP).   Employees are trained on and are provided access to the hydrogen process safety information.  The specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan.  Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation. participating in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are correct and recommend any necessary changes.

 

Safe & Hot Work Permit System

Air Liquide has a safe & hot work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures and standards under the life safety program.  Procedures in place include:  energy control, safe work,  hot work, con

fined space entry and process line break.  Facility personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

 

Contractors

Air Liquide uses outside contractors to support maintenance activities.  Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by PSM/RMP.  Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors:  (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the hydrogen purification process.

 

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Air Liquide's accidental release prevention program activities helps prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.  The following are examples of the types of safety features in place:

 

?        Personal/portable ambient air monitor

?        Release Mitigation

?        PSV

?        Flare

?        Fire water monitors

?        Special personal protective equipment (e.g., FRC protective clothing,)

?        Automatic control and manual valves that provide for isolation of the process equipment 

 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Freeport HPU has no accidents resulting in catastrophic consequence onsite or offsite in the past 5 year.

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

 The Air Liquide Freeport HPU facility maintains a written emergency action plan (EAP) which includes the Freeport SMR.   The Freeport HPU EAP is reviewed and trained on annually.  The Freeport HPU employees are trained to first responder awareness level to be ready in the event of accidental releases of a regulated substance.   The EAP provides details for the safe evacuation of facility personnel, contr

actors and visitors.  The EAP describes coordination with Dow Oyster Creek Emergency Response Team.  The EAP plan contains outside agency the notification process and information on emergency health care in the event of a loss of containment of the Freeport HPU flammable substance process.   



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Freeport HPU resolves all findings of its PHA and other hazard reviews some of which result in modifications of the process.  For example from the most recent PHA plant replaced emergency shutdown motor operated valves (MOV) from electric motor to fail closed pneumatic  to address plant electrical power loss.
